Stem: Usually hairless, branching higher up. Creeping stems produce roots at joints.
Leaves: Flat blades 15-35 cm long. With a mostly hairless sheath.
Flowers: Heads of between 6 and 18 dense long greenish to reddish spikes radiating from the same point, each 5-10 cm long and spreading or somewhat drooping.
FruitSeeds: Spikelets turn brown or straw-coloured and drop off leaving pair of bracts on head containing egg-shaped flattened seeds.
Habitat: Parks, gardens, grasslands, railways, roadsides, pastures, cropping areas.
DistinguishingFeatures: Generally very similar but less hairy than other Rhodes grasses (*Chloris* species).
